Right"},"value":{"value":"bottom-right"}}},"renderMode":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Collapsible"},"value":{"value":"default"}}},"isAboutAuthor":{"boolValue":false},"background":{"targetItem":null},"image":{"src":null,"alt":""}},{"mediaID":{"value":"2"},"description":{"jsonValue":{"value":"\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eGeerte Udo was CEO\u003c/strong\u003e of Amsterdam \u0026amp; Partners    until earlier this year, when she stepped down after 17 years. Amsterdam \u0026amp; Partners is a public\u0026ndash;private foundation that focuses, in part, on managing tourism in the Amsterdam metropolitan area. McKinsey spoke with Udo about Amsterdam\u0026rsquo;s efforts to handle its large tourist flows. The following is an edited version of the conversation.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eMcKinsey:\u003c/strong\u003e How does Amsterdam balance the positive aspects of tourism with some of the challenges that hosting large numbers of visitors can create?\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Image 1]]\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eGeerte Udo:\u003c/strong\u003e We\u0026rsquo;re\u0026nbsp;very lucky in that we have a beautiful city that sells itself. People want to come here. And the visitor economy has a lot of benefits. It creates jobs, it pays taxes, and 30 percent of our public transport is financed by visitors. Our residents love the cultural infrastructure we have here, and we couldn\u0026rsquo;t\u0026nbsp;support it by ourselves. We love the diversity and quality of our restaurants and bars, which are also supported by visitors. We need our visitors because they raise the quality of life for our residents.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBut there are elements of the visitor economy that can harm the quality of life in the city. We\u0026rsquo;re seeing more and more visitors because the general income of people across the world is rising, and everybody wants to travel. Like other European cities that are old harbor cities with narrow streets, we have moments where we deal with overcrowding. This is mostly in the old city center, on a few narrow streets, at certain days and times. But the public space there isn\u0026rsquo;t\u0026nbsp;well organized and can\u0026rsquo;t handle the number of people who want to go there.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAnother issue we have is nuisance. Our city has a reputation: if you want to have a party, come to Amsterdam. It can be very annoying for residents in certain neighborhoods when visitors come to party from Thursday through Sunday evening. It makes it hard for people to live there.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThere\u0026rsquo;s also an issue with managing the amount of waste in the city. Because we have more guests, there\u0026rsquo;s\u0026nbsp;more waste in the street. And there\u0026rsquo;s a separate issue with private, short-term rental properties, which can sometimes crowd out housing that\u0026rsquo;s built for residents.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eMcKinsey:\u003c/strong\u003e Are you able to gather data and use it to get insights that can help you handle tourist flows?\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eGeerte Udo:\u003c/strong\u003e We have a lot of sources of data. At a European level, we share data with 110 European cities to see what the latest traveler trends are. We can learn from one another and understand, for instance, if a trend is only happening in the northern part of Europe or also in the southern part. More locally, we have a national data center that can tell us how many people visit the city, how long they stay, which countries they come from, their ages, and other factual information.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOur organization also does its own research on visitor behavior. For instance, we sell an I amsterdam City Card. It gives visitors free access to public transport, museums, and various attractions. We sell about 150,000 to 200,000 cards a year, and because people need to check in with our card at the locations, we can see their movement patterns. Over time, we\u0026rsquo;re able to anticipate when and where people will go. For instance, many people visit museums in the morning and then go on a canal boat ride in the afternoon. We can advise first-time visitors to reverse that order because they\u0026rsquo;re likely to have better, less crowded experiences that way.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBut nudging people only works if you can connect to their needs. We wouldn\u0026rsquo;t tell a first-time visitor to venture out to a neighborhood that\u0026rsquo;s not well-known\u0026mdash;we understand that if they\u0026rsquo;re here for the first time, they really want to see the highlights. Whereas if you\u0026rsquo;re here for the third time, and we know what you\u0026rsquo;ve been doing and a little bit about your preferences, we can guide you to other neighborhoods and areas we think you\u0026rsquo;ll enjoy.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWe know from data that there\u0026rsquo;s a trend in behavior where, after 2.4 days, people are often ready to explore beyond the city. This number is similar in other cities, as well. After 2.4 days, people start to ask, \u0026ldquo;Can you show me where I can get some fresh air for a half day?\u0026rdquo; And we can then offer them guidance on visiting beaches, windmills, and so forth.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eMcKinsey:\u003c/strong\u003e What are some mitigation strategies that you\u0026rsquo;ve tried or considered?\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eGeerte Udo:\u003c/strong\u003e One thing we\u0026rsquo;ve put effort into is branding and marketing concepts. If people come to our city thinking that everything is in the canal district, it\u0026rsquo;s hard to guide them to other areas. So we\u0026rsquo;ve tried to build our image into much more than the canal district, expanding interest into other areas that all have different identities and different flavors.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThere have been years of discussions about gating certain areas and charging fees to enter them. That might help generate revenue that the city can spend on cleaning streets and improving the subways, which would be beneficial for the tourism industry. But in my opinion, charging fees or raising tourist taxes won\u0026rsquo;t reduce visitor numbers at all.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWe\u0026rsquo;ve spent a lot of time with city hall looking into the best ways to organize public spaces. For a long time, urban planning didn\u0026rsquo;t even take visitors into account when thinking about how to arrange public space. To truly manage visitor flows, there needs to be a bigger-picture, integrated approach to how a city is organized.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eNone of this will reduce the number of travelers because travel is growing so fast. But we can guide visitors to disperse them across time and space, minimize overcrowding, and put less pressure on the old city center. I think guiding and spreading tourism really can work if we manage to match supply and demand.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eComments and opinions expressed by interviewees are their own and do not represent or reflect the opinions, policies, or positions of McKinsey \u0026amp; Company or have its endorsement.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e"}},"aboutTheAuthors":{"jsonValue":{"value":""}},"headline":{"jsonValue":{"value":"How Amsterdam handles its tourist flows"}},"footnotes":{"value":""},"showShareTools":{"boolValue":true},"backgroundColor":{"targetItem":null},"gradientDirection":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Bottom Right"},"value":{"value":"bottom-right"}}},"renderMode":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Scrolling"},"value":{"value":"scrolling"}}},"isAboutAuthor":{"boolValue":false},"background":{"targetItem":null},"image":{"src":null,"alt":""}},{"mediaID":{"value":"1"},"description":{"jsonValue":{"value":"\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eUtilizing information\u003c/strong\u003e from vendors, publicly available databases, and press searches, we measured airline traffic, accommodation booking activity, and traveler sentiment.[[footnote 1]] We also incorporated analysis of data sets obtained from travel-focused groups such as the UN World Tourism Organization and the World Travel \u0026amp; Tourism Council.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOur intent was to identify metrics that indicate the potential effects of concentrated tourism. We examined metrics affecting the following six categories:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eLocal economy:\u003c/em\u003e measuring the potential risk of dependence on tourism based on the speed of tourism growth over the past five years and tourism\u0026rsquo;s contribution to direct employment and GDP.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eLocal community:\u003c/em\u003e measuring the concentration of tourism in city centers based on inbound arrivals, nights stayed, and tourism accommodations per square kilometer.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eTourist experience:\u003c/em\u003e measuring overall tourist sentiment based on reviews of top 20 attractions and guest satisfaction regarding accommodations.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eInfrastructure:\u003c/em\u003e measuring potential overloading risks caused by tourism based on the seasonal intensity and geographic concentration of visitor arrivals.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eNature and the environment:\u003c/em\u003e measuring risks to nature based on carbon emissions generated by travel and sustainability commitments pledged by local hotels.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eCulture and heritage:\u003c/em\u003e measuring potential threats to cultural sites based on the concentration of visitors at these sites.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e"}},"aboutTheAuthors":{"jsonValue":{"value":""}},"headline":{"jsonValue":{"value":"Methodology for assessing destination readiness"}},"footnotes":{"value":"\u003col\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eDiio Mi; International Air Transport Association; Mabrian Technologies; Oxford Economics; Tripadvisor; UN World Tourism Organization; World Travel \u0026amp; Tourism Council.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ol\u003e"},"showShareTools":{"boolValue":true},"backgroundColor":{"targetItem":null},"gradientDirection":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Bottom Right"},"value":{"value":"bottom-right"}}},"renderMode":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Collapsible"},"value":{"value":"default"}}},"isAboutAuthor":{"boolValue":false},"background":{"targetItem":null},"image":{"src":null,"alt":""}}]},"globalsidebar":{"results":[]},"video":{"results":[]},"scrollycontainer":{"results":[{"id":"354A9D85924F41E8826C9532F8762A10","mediaID":{"value":"1"},"scrollySettings":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"two-column"},"value":{"value":"two-column"}}},"edgeToEdge":{"boolValue":false},"collapseTopSpace":{"boolValue":false},"collapseBottomSpace":{"boolValue":false},"desktopTextColumnWidth":{"targetItem":null},"mediaPlacement":{"targetItem":null},"backgroundTheme":{"targetItem":null},"eyebrow":{"value":"Exhibit 3"},"displayNumber":{"value":""},"mobileTwoColumnStacked":{"boolValue":false},"scaleBackgroundImageOneColumn":{"boolValue":false},"children":{"results":[{"id":"EA4B6303E60B4E13B9524C10FFDF0684","name":"Exhibit for Scrolly 1","template":{"name":"ExhibitForScrolly"},"title":{"value":"Seasonally overloaded: Dubrovnik"},"description":{"value":"\u003cp\u003eDubrovnik is an intensely seasonal destination, with roughly 20 times more inbound airline seats made available for sale   during its peak season (July and August) than during low season (January and February). The density of vacation rentals can reach about 90 postings per square kilometer in summer. The city is a popular stop for Mediterranean cruises, and its small, history-laden center can experience concentrated tourist footfalls when a ship is in port.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eDubrovnik falls in the top quintile of risk in four of our six categories, although it has begun taking significant steps to combat overcrowding. The city recently banned new private-rental permits in its historic Old Town neighborhood to counter rising rent costs for locals,[[footnote 1]] and it\u0026rsquo;s also reorganizing cruise schedules to better stagger visitor flows.\u003c/p\u003e"},"textComponentPlacement":{"targetItem":null},"textComponentBackgroundColor":{"targetItem":null},"exhibitImage":{"src":"/~/media/mckinsey/industries/travel logistics and infrastructure/our insights/destination readiness preparing for the tourist flows of tomorrow/svgz_sot-destinationreadiness_exscrolly3a.svgz","alt":"Destinations can assess tourism preparedness across six dimensions.","description":""},"mobileExhibit":{"src":null,"alt":"","description":null},"footnotes":{"value":"\u003col\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eSanjana Shenoy, \u0026ldquo;Croatia: Historic city Dubrovnik bans new rental permits to curb overtourism \u0026amp; help locals,\u0026rdquo; Curly Tales, March 15, 2024.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ol\u003e"}},{"id":"31389B7700E549708D48D406B5FA874C","name":"Exhibit for Scrolly 2","template":{"name":"ExhibitForScrolly"},"title":{"value":"Increasingly stressed: Mumbai"},"description":{"value":"\u003cp\u003eMumbai is well positioned to capitalize on booming Indian tourism, but the city could benefit from building out its visitor-management-flow systems. Mumbai has the lowest tourism density relative to its population of all cities in our data set, yet visitors report some of the same concerns seen in more popular tourism hot spots, including long waits for entrance to attractions and a plethora of guides and vendors competing for attention. Road traffic is a major detriment to the visitor experience, with tourists in 2023 experiencing an average travel time of 20 minutes to cover ten kilometers.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe city has ambitious plans to reduce congestion with new metro and highway systems that could benefit both locals and tourists. It might have additional room to increase carrying capacity by addressing current visitor pain points\u0026mdash;for example, by installing modernized metal detectors to smooth entry into major attractions or by creating centralized guide booths at attractions to help visitors find licensed guides.\u003c/p\u003e"},"textComponentPlacement":{"targetItem":null},"textComponentBackgroundColor":{"targetItem":null},"exhibitImage":{"src":"/~/media/mckinsey/industries/travel logistics and infrastructure/our insights/destination readiness preparing for the tourist flows of tomorrow/svgz_sot-destinationreadiness_exscrolly3b.svgz","alt":"Destinations can assess tourism preparedness across six dimensions.","description":""},"mobileExhibit":{"src":null,"alt":"","description":null},"footnotes":{"value":""}},{"id":"7D0ACF89EE804F20AF33A61C397868D6","name":"Exhibit for Scrolly 3","template":{"name":"ExhibitForScrolly"},"title":{"value":"Actively managed: Amsterdam"},"description":{"value":"\u003cp\u003eGiven Amsterdam\u0026rsquo;s small geographic footprint, its extreme concentration of visitors puts significant pressure on local infrastructure\u0026mdash;affecting the daily experiences of both tourists and residents. It has tried to actively manage tourism through measures such as its recently announced moratorium on hotel development[[footnote 1]] and a ban on public smoking of cannabis in its red-light district.[[footnote 2]] It has also used marketing to promote less-well-known areas in an effort to channel some visitors away from the most crowded neighborhoods. Amsterdam uses data gleaned from social media and behavior tracked on its tourist-friendly city card to analyze tourist flows and spot areas under stress.\u003c/p\u003e"},"textComponentPlacement":{"targetItem":null},"textComponentBackgroundColor":{"targetItem":null},"exhibitImage":{"src":"/~/media/mckinsey/industries/travel logistics and infrastructure/our insights/destination readiness preparing for the tourist flows of tomorrow/svgz_sot-destinationreadiness_exscrolly3c.svgz","alt":"Destinations can assess tourism preparedness across six dimensions.","description":""},"mobileExhibit":{"src":null,"alt":"","description":null},"footnotes":{"value":"\u003col\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eCharlotte Van Campenhout, \u0026ldquo;Amsterdam bans new hotels in fight against mass tourism,\u0026rdquo; Reuters, April 17, 2024.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u0026ldquo;Amsterdam to ban cannabis outdoors in red-light district,\u0026rdquo; Reuters, February 10, 2023.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ol\u003e"}},{"id":"9E278F72271E4FB3A487B9BFF5960B92","name":"Exhibit for Scrolly 4","template":{"name":"ExhibitForScrolly"},"title":{"value":"Balanced capacity: Singapore"},"description":{"value":"\u003cp\u003eRenowned for an automated metro train line, futuristic downtown core, and cutting-edge innovation, Singapore has the infrastructure, resources, and practices in place to grow and support larger tourism flows. It currently ranks 56th out of the 65 cities we analyzed in terms of inbound visits per square kilometer.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSingapore\u0026rsquo;s limited land mass does tend to concentrate visitor flows at top attractions, which could affect experiences at these sites for both tourists and residents. Recent development projects have expanded the depth and breadth of tourist offerings, creating new attractions that could help increase the city\u0026rsquo;s carrying capacity and keep it primed for
